title: Odd Process
statementHtml:
You have nn coins with denominations a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an and a natural number kk. You also have a bag, which is initially empty, where you can place coins. You need to perform exactly kk actions. In each action, you take one coin from those you have left and put it in your bag. After that, you can no longer take that coin.

At the same time, you have a cat that loves even numbers, so every time the sum of the denominations of the coins in your bag becomes even, your cat empties the bag, meaning it takes all the coins to a place known only to it, and the bag is empty again. Note that the bag is emptied every time the sum becomes even during the process of adding coins, not just at the very last moment.

Let your score be the sum of the denominations of the coins in the bag. Your task is to perform kk actions such that your final score is maximized. Find the answer for all 1≤k≤n1≤k≤n.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of coins you have.

The second line of each test case contains nn natural numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the denominations of the coins.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output nn numbers — the maximum possible score that can be achieved by performing exactly kk actions for all kk from 11 to nn.
noteHtml:
In the first set of input data, you have coins with denominations [1,1,11,1,1].

  • k=1k=1: in this case, the sum of the denominations in the bag is 11, regardless of the chosen coin. The final score is also 11.
  • k=2k=2: in this case, the sum of the denominations in the bag is initially 11, regardless of the choice of coin. When choosing the second coin, the sum will be 22, regardless of the choice of coin, and thus the bag will be emptied. The final score is 00.
  • k=3k=3: in this case, when choosing the first two coins, the sum will be 22 and the bag will be emptied, after which the sum will be 00. When choosing the third coin, the sum will become 11.

In the second set of input data, you have coins with denominations [1,2,31,2,3].

  • k=1k=1: in this case, when choosing the coin with denomination 22, the bag will be emptied and the final score will be 00. When choosing the coin with denomination 11 or 33, the final scores will be 11 and 33, respectively. The maximum possible final score is 33.
  • k=2k=2: in this case, when choosing two coins 11 and 33 in any order, their sum will be 44, after which the bag will be emptied and the final score will be 00. However, when choosing 33 as the first coin, the score will be 33. Then you can choose, for example, coin 22, and the final score will become 55.
  • k=3k=3: in this case, the sum of all coins will be 66, and since each time the bag is emptied it does not change the parity of the accumulated sum, the final score is 00.
